children.value: Introduction
Motivation

The purpose of the ECM is to capture show the short-run dynamics of the variables n the system are influenced by the deviation from the long-run equilibrium. If we are out of equilibrium, then we will move back into the equilibrium, and the model captures this. We difference the data to ensure that any regressions will not be spurious (for reasons mentioned in 1). However, if we just differenced them and regressed them on another, we fail to capture the long-run relationship between the 2 variables that exists (due to the fact they are cointegrated). Hence, we can capture that with the ECM as any time series that is not in equilibrium will move back into equilibrium according to the magnitude of the disequilibrium.
Derivation
First we begin with 2 I(1) variables that are cointegrated
yty_tyt​
and
ztz_tzt​
. From this, we know that we can express it as:
ηt=yt−α−βzt\eta_t = y_t - \alpha - \beta z_tηt​=yt​−α−βzt​
We will keep this in mind for later. Now let us define our general model whereby we are looking at the relationship between
yty_tyt​
and
ztz_tzt​
alongside 1 lag.
yt=α0+α1yt−1+β0zt+β1zt−1+ϵty_t = \alpha_0 + \alpha_1y_{t-1} + \beta_0z_t + \beta_1z_{t-1} + \epsilon_tyt​=α0​+α1​yt−1​+β0​zt​+β1​zt−1​+ϵt​
We note that
yty_tyt​
and
ztz_tzt​
are I(1), so we need to difference them. First we difference
yty_tyt​
yt−yt−1=α0+α1yt−1−yt−1+β0zt+β1zt−1+ϵty_t - y_{t-1}= \alpha_0 + \alpha_1y_{t-1} - y_{t-1} + \beta_0z_t + \beta_1z_{t-1} + \epsilon_tyt​−yt−1​=α0​+α1​yt−1​−yt−1​+β0​zt​+β1​zt−1​+ϵt​
Δyt=α0+(α1−1)yt−1+β0zt+β1zt−1+ϵt\Delta y_t = \alpha_0 + (\alpha_1 - 1)y_{t-1} + \beta_0z_t + \beta_1z_{t-1} + \epsilon_tΔyt​=α0​+(α1​−1)yt−1​+β0​zt​+β1​zt−1​+ϵt​
Then we add and subtract
β0Zt−1\beta_0 Z_{t-1}β0​Zt−1​
on the RHS to difference it.

Δyt=α0+(α1−1)yt−1+β0zt−β0zt−1+β0zt−1+β1zt−1+ϵt\Delta y_t = \alpha_0 + (\alpha_1 - 1)y_{t-1} + \beta_0z_t - \beta_0 z_{t-1} + \beta_0 z_{t-1} + \beta_1z_{t-1} + \epsilon_tΔyt​=α0​+(α1​−1)yt−1​+β0​zt​−β0​zt−1​+β0​zt−1​+β1​zt−1​+ϵt​

Δyt=α0+(α1−1)yt−1+β0Δzt+β0zt−1+β1zt−1+ϵt\Delta y_t = \alpha_0 + (\alpha_1 - 1)y_{t-1} + \beta_0\Delta z_t + \beta_0z_{t-1} + \beta_1z_{t-1} + \epsilon_tΔyt​=α0​+(α1​−1)yt−1​+β0​Δzt​+β0​zt−1​+β1​zt−1​+ϵt​
We can then do this little trick:

Δyt=α0−(1−α1)yt−1+β0Δzt+β0zt−1+β1zt−1+ϵt\Delta y_t = \alpha_0 - (1 - \alpha_1)y_{t-1} + \beta_0\Delta z_t + \beta_0z_{t-1} + \beta_1z_{t-1} + \epsilon_tΔyt​=α0​−(1−α1​)yt−1​+β0​Δzt​+β0​zt−1​+β1​zt−1​+ϵt​

Δyt=δ+β0Δzt−(1−α1)[yt−1−β0+β11−α1zt−1−α)+ϵt\Delta y_t = \delta + \beta_0\Delta z_t - (1 - \alpha_1)[y_{t-1} - \frac{\beta_0 + \beta_1}{1 - \alpha_1}z_{t-1} - \alpha) + \epsilon_tΔyt​=δ+β0​Δzt​−(1−α1​)[yt−1​−1−α1​β0​+β1​​zt−1​−α)+ϵt​
where if you look carefully, I split the
α0\alpha_0α0​
term up into
δ\deltaδ
and
α\alphaα
. Note also the term in the bracket is simply
ηt−1\eta_{t-1}ηt−1​
Δyt=δ+β0Δzt−(1−α1)[ηt−1]+ϵt\Delta y_t = \delta + \beta_0\Delta z_t - (1 - \alpha_1)[\eta_{t-1}] + \epsilon_tΔyt​=δ+β0​Δzt​−(1−α1​)[ηt−1​]+ϵt​
Δyt=δ+β0Δzt+(α1−1)[ηt−1]+ϵt\Delta y_t = \delta + \beta_0\Delta z_t + (\alpha_1 - 1)[\eta_{t-1}] + \epsilon_tΔyt​=δ+β0​Δzt​+(α1​−1)[ηt−1​]+ϵt​
We can then redefine some of the variables to match the standard notation.
Δyt=δ+θΔzt+γηt−1+ϵt\Delta y_t = \delta + \theta\Delta z_t + \gamma\eta_{t-1} + \epsilon_tΔyt​=δ+θΔzt​+γηt−1​+ϵt​
